Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Large Hail Accumulations in Thunderstorms
Award.AbstractNarration:
Thunderstorms that produce deep hail accumulations pose a substantial risk to life and property resulting in motor vehicle accidents, road closures, airport delays, urban and river flooding, and water rescues. Data inhomogeneities and inadequacies in monitoring hail characteristics in thunderstorms leads to low confident in projecting future hail occurrence and evaluation of future climate predictions. The overarching goal of the research is to analyze the microphysical and dynamical conditions necessary for large amounts of in-cloud hail production that lead to deep surface hail accumulations by developing and validating a robust set of characteristic storm properties unique to significant hail accumulation; determining the role of mechanisms enhancing hail production; and determining temporal and spatial variation of hail accumulations in observations and simulations.

Intellectual Merit:
The intellectual merit lies in its contribution to a comprehensive understanding of the dual-polarization and lighting characteristics in severe thunderstorms with significant hail accumulations; how and why they are linked to environmental conditions, storm morphology, terrain, and outflow boundaries; and if state-of-the-art regional climate and weather forecasting models are capable of reproducing hail accumulation characteristics derived from observations. The research will advance our understanding of processes contributing to large hail/graupel production in thunderstorms, improve the forecasting of extreme events that cause natural disasters, and extend current capabilities to directly benefit society.

Broader Impacts:
The broader impacts are that the studies will aid in better forecasting and nowcasting events with significant hail accumulation and provide basis for evaluating forecasting and regional climate simulations. Hailstorms have had large economical impacts through damage to property and agriculture with livestock fatalities and human injuries. This study will provide better insight if hail accumulation also provides useful information to issue reliable warnings to the public and assistance in severe weather management. Undergraduates and graduate students will participate in the scientific research through independent studies, internships, and a Ph.D. thesis. The project will promote the collaborations between the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research's Significant Opportunities in Atmospheric Research and Science program and the University of Colorado's Summer Multicultural Access to Research Training program, which are intended for underrepresented undergraduate students in science, math, and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal is to analyze the microphysical and dynamical conditions necessary for large amounts of in-cloud hail production that lead to deep surface hail accumulations. This project is a collaborative effort between the UCAR SOARS? Program, the University of Colorado, Boulder, and the National Weather Service Forecast Office Boulder. It involves analyses of radar and lightning data from hail-producing and non-hail-producing thunderstorms and the analysis of numerical simulations using the experimental and operational HRRR model (3 km resolution every 15 minutes) for selected events and 12-year regional climate simulations conducted with the C-WRF model (4 km resolution every hour).
The first year of the grant extended from September 1, 2016 through August 31, 2017. The project has been renamed to the Colorado Hail Accumulations from Thunderstorms (CHAT).

The SOARS program is a year-round undergraduate to graduate bridge program aimed at increasing the diversity of the atmospheric sciences. SOARS supports historically underrepresented students to enter and succeed in graduate school and STEM careers, and develop the next generation of leadership in the field.

The project provided professional development over the performance period to one graduate student, Bobby Wallace, one undergraduate student, Bailey Donaldson, and supported three undergraduates participating in the SOARS Program, Michaela Serpas (2018,19); Jordan Benjamin (2019, 20); and Angelie Nieves-Jimenez (2020).

Michaela Serpas, a math major from the Colorado School of Mines received the SOARS fellowship, which was part of this NSF award and worked over the summer in 2018 on the CHAT project. The work continued with Michaela throughout the academic year to finish up hail depth climatology for the Colorado Front Range and the analysis of environmental conditions during hail-accumulating events versus non-hail-accumulating events.

Jordan Benjamin, a physics major from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, received the 2019 SOARS fellowship, and worked on CHAT project.

In year 2, results were presented at international conferences (e.g., 29th Conference on Severe Local Storms, Stowe, VT; AMS 99th Annual Meeting), the ATOC colloquium at the U. of Colorado, and 12th Annual Earth System and Space Science Poster Conference at Boulder CO. All of the presentations were given by the students Wallace and Serpas.

Benjamin, J., K. Friedrich, G. Thompson, 2019: Validating Hail Production and Hail Size from the New 3-Moment Thompson Microphysical Scheme. 2019 SOARS Colloquium and SOARS Joint Internship Poster Session, Boulder CO.

Serpas, M., K. Friedrich, R. Wallace: Statistical Analysis of Hail-Accumulating Thunderstorm Occurrence along the Colorado Front Range. Special Symposium on Mesoscale Meteorological Extremes: Understanding, Prediction, and Projection (AMS 99th Annual Meeting). Phoenix, AZ. January 2019.

The third year of the grant extended from September 1, 2019 through August 31, 2020. A no-cost extension has been granted until August 31, 2021. During the third year, thus far, some of the following accomplishments are:

i)            summarized results on radar and lightning characteristics of hail-producing versus non-hail-producing thunderstorms in a journal publication, and

ii)           started to validate hail accumulations from WRF simulations using newly-developed Thompson 3-moment microphysics scheme for thunderstorms in eastern Colorado and Kansas in May 2019 (in collaboration with SOARS).

iii)         Friedrich, K., M. Serpas, R. Wallace: Frequency and distribution of hail accumulation events along the Colorado Wyoming Front Range.

In year 3, results were presented at the 100th AMS Annual Meeting, Boston, MA, the ATOC colloquium at the U. of Colorado, and 13th Annual Earth System and Space Science Poster Conference at Boulder CO. All of the presentations were given by Wallace.

 *For the summer of 2020, SOARS held a virtual program that was ten weeks in length.  The additional funds designated for prot?g?s on this NSF award went to support prot?g? Angelie Nieves-Jim?nez. Angelie, a junior Industrial Engineering major from the University of Puerto Rico, Mayag?ez, participated in a Cohort of eight returning Prot?g?s.  From May through July, Angelie received 10 weeks of the Scientific Communication and Writing workshop; nine weeks of Computation and Data Science workshop, and extensive professional development during the ten weeks. 

 Her research mentors from NCAR were Dr. Kelly Werner and Dr. Rosimar Rios-Berrios, both from the Mesoscale, Microscale & Meteorology Lab.  Her writing mentor was Dr. Nan Rosenbloom, of NCAR?s Climate and Global Dynamics Lab.  Angelie?s research project was titled, ?Sea Breeze, Trade Wind, and Terrain Influence on Rainfall Location over Western Puerto Rico?.  Angelie presented this research in a final talk at the 2020 Colloquium, in a poster presentation at the NCAR|UCAR Virtual Poster Symposium, and submitted an abstract and final paper to be published in Earth, Wind, Sea, and Sky and the Open Sky repository.
